snippet: Maaloula has long symbolized Syria’s history of diversity and coexistence, but most of its residents have fled after fighting between rebels and government forces.
abstract: Residents of ancient Christian town of Maaloula, Syria, long a symbol of Syria’s history of diversity and coexistence, have fled after arrival of fighting between rebels and government forces; rebel incursion into town, led by Islamic extremists, reinforces worst fears of Syrian Christians and will likely cast doubt on Pres Obama's arguments that military strike against Bashar al-Assad will not strengthen Islamic extremists.

byline.original: By ANNE BARNARD and HWAIDA SAAD
byline.contributor: An employee of The New York Times contributed reporting.

lead_paragraph: Maaloula has long symbolized Syria’s history of diversity and coexistence, but most of its residents have fled after fighting between rebels and government forces.

headline.main: Assault on Christian Town in Syria Adds to Fears Over Rebels
headline.print_headline: Assault on Christian Town in Syria Adds to the Fears Over Rebels

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
